content.text: Your hero has stats now, but the villagers are not impressed. They shout: "Traveler, tell us your name! How many coins do you carry? How strong are you?"
To answer them, your hero needs to listen and respond. This is where we use input() and friendly output.

items: Input ‚Üí let the player type information
Casting ‚Üí convert input text into numbers
Print (f-strings) ‚Üí produce clean, friendly output

content.text: The input() function is your hero‚Äôs ears üëÇ. It lets the player type something in, and the hero remembers it.

hero_name = input("What is your hero's name? ")
print("Welcome,", hero_name)
Important: Everything typed in with input() is stored as text (a string), even if it looks like a number.

items: Use input() to ask: ‚ÄúHow many coins do you carry?‚Äù
Print: "You have X coins." (replace X with the answer).

content.text:
hero_coins = input("How many coins do you carry? ")
print("You have", hero_coins, "coins.")
Sometimes the villagers give you numbers, but they arrive as text scrolls üìú. To use them for math, you must turn them into numbers. This is called casting.

items: int() ‚Üí makes an integer (whole number)
float() ‚Üí makes a decimal number

content.text:
coins = int(input("How many coins do you carry? "))
attack = float(input("What is your attack power? "))
Now you can do math:

coins += 5
print("After treasure, you have", coins, "coins.")

items: Use float(input()) to ask for attack power.
Add 2.5 to the attack power (magic boost).
Print the boosted power.

content.text:
hero_attack = float(input("What is your attack power? "))
hero_attack += 2.5
print("With a magic boost, your attack is now", hero_attack)
Using commas with print() works fine, but Python also has a magic shortcut called f-strings. It‚Äôs like inserting variables directly into your sentence.

hero_name = "Kai"
hero_hp = 100
print(f"Welcome {hero_name}! You start with {hero_hp} HP.")
F-strings make your game output look cleaner and easier to write.

items: Ask for hero‚Äôs name with input().
Give them 100 HP automatically.

The villagers surround you and ask three questions: ‚ÄúWhat is your name?‚Äù ‚ÄúHow many coins do you carry?‚Äù ‚ÄúWhat is your attack power?‚Äù

instructions: Ask for attack power (cast to float).
Print a full hero introduction using f-strings.

hero_name = input("What is your hero's name? ")

print(f"Welcome {hero_name}!")

items: Use input() so the hero can listen to players.
Cast input into numbers with int() and float() for math.
Use f-strings to print clean, friendly sentences.
